issues.title: need to close the term thing (see list issues in the draft)
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
*  The terms of ‘digital twin network’ and ‘network digital twin’
  should be clarified.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: It was discussed in recently nmrg interim meeting, it was agreed to change digital twin network into network digital twin.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: Thanks Qin. See the PR to fix that.

issues.title: Sample Application Scenarios
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
*  In section of 'Sample Application Scenarios', to dig deeper into
  one or two use cases.

is this one still pending?

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Do we have intent translation, sadbox use case? How NDT elements are related to use cases? These issues are raised in recent interim meeting.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Fixed in https://github.com/cheneyzhoucheng/network-digital-twin/commit/c649a164ef46ab3a31c5fa1239e9e9efc3ffaaf2

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Can we see digial twin as a tool
"
digital twins are a powerful tool for scenario planning, impact analysis, and change management. This powerful combination allows network maintenance engineer or network designer to test and model optimisation strategies in a risk-free environment, ensuring that only the most effective changes are implemented in the real network. Digital twins also play a crucial role in root cause analysis, providing a sandbox for testing hypotheses and validating the outcomes of data-driven insights without impacting end users. 
"

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
My suggested the scope for Network digital twin concept as follows:
1. Introduction
2. Terminology
3. Introduction of Concept
4. Characteristics of Network Digital Twin
5. Network Digital Twin: Functionality
6. Lifecycle
7. IANA Consideration
8. Security Consideration
9. Informative References
We can consider to separate how network digital twin can be integrated into the management sytem as a second document.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: I don't get the comment. Is there a concern to separate the reference arch vs. concept?

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
yes, the comment is from Interim meeting,  Chris debate we are working on controller architecture, he think model architecture can be used in other SDOs, it was incidated by nmrg chairs, this draft could be split into two documents,  to achieve this, a new design team should be setup to faciliate discussing this work.
See his slides proposed in the interim and previous IETF:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/slides-interim-2024-nmrg-01-sessa-proposed-modifications-to-dtn-concept-and-architecture-draft/

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Data, Model, Mapping, Interface are four NDT characterisitcs or four phase of NDT lifecycle management?
where do we position emulation?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Data, Model, Mapping, Interface are four NDT characterisitcs or four phase of NDT lifecycle management?

These are not phases.

> where do we position emulation?

emulate/control/diag/etc. are core functions of the twin engine.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: This is something Chris argue about in the interim.  the question is do we develop new network management platform with digital twin integrated, or do we develop network digital twin component?

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body: I don't understand how it makes sense to call a range of functions as broad as emulation, diagnosis, control, "etc." as a "core functions" of an engine. It's tantamount to saying an NDT does anything and everything. Doesn't it make more sense to talk about NDT core functions that are closer to emulation/modeling based on network data, and then show how those core functions can be composed with other functions, to construct progressively more complex engines that serve different applications?

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Already clarified in section 3.3, quote text as follows:
"
Note: Real-time interaction is not always mandatory for all twins. When testing some configuration changes or trying some innovative techniques, the digital twins can behave as a simulation platform without the need of real time telemetry data. And even in this scenario, it is better to have interactive mapping capability so that the validated changes can be tested in real network whenever required by the testers. In most other cases (e.g., network optimization, network fault recovery), real-time interaction between virtual and real network is mandatory. This way, network digital twin can help achieve the goal of autonomous network or self-driven network.
"

issues.title: Clarification on Bi-directional interaction
issues.author: cheneyzhoucheng
issues.body:
- It is not possible or necessary to 'synchronize' all twin states or flows to physical entity. 
- Bi-directional interaction means that: data/states/flows reported or collected from physical to twin, and configure changes or 'necessary' data sent from twin to physical.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Clarified in https://github.com/cheneyzhoucheng/network-digital-twin/commit/efab85d6d080deab03c15417978f1e0a7c55e6dc

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> * It is not possible or necessary to 'synchronize' all twin states or flows to physical entity.

@billwuqin, I suggest we add an explicit sentence to indicate that "the mirroring pace and scope" should be controlled for a given twin instance.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Good comment, we haven't explored  mirroring pace and scope.  I think mirroring pace and scope needs to be further expanded.

issues.title: Architecture update on Figure 2
issues.author: cheneyzhoucheng
issues.body:
- Inner closed-loop: iterative simulation and verification in twin layer. Outer closed-loop validation and optimization.
- Orchestration for models and resources can be included in NDT mgmt module 
- etc.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Related to scope of NDT. We need to decide how to separate network digital twin as a tool from network managemet sytem or orchestrator

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body: Sorry for jumping in late. As you know, my "criticisms" were that the NDT was too closely identified functionally as a controller, and that the presentation of architecture left major gaps between the modeling function and the remainder (e.g., inner and outer closed loops were not discussed or depicted). That said, I think the presentation and discussion at Brisbane show we do in fact have a pretty close conceptual view. You proposed there to reorient the draft toward "concept only" and in fact Colin advised that IRTF should not get into architecture; I think that's a little over the top but in any case.

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body: I think it is possible to split the difference, by describing architecture on a high level, conceptual basis. Describe a core function based on data and modeling; then describe the composition of closed loops using that core function plus others; then describe how those closed loops can be used in automation architectures (some of which might be controllers, some might be limited to planning and management, etc.) In this description, I think it is easiest to call the "core function" the NDT (full stop), but you can call it the NDT core functions if you still prefer some ambiguity. Once that's done, it is easy to consider use cases.

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body: If you like this idea we can discuss a matching outline and what content would need change or addition.

pulls.title: clarify that not all functions may be supported + various other edits

comments.body: The proposed changes make sense to me. For the next step, we need to incorporate more comments recieved from NMRG interim organized by chairs.

comments.body:

Can you please record these comments as issues so that we are all in sync, and then discuss them? Thanks, @billwuqin

comments.body: Agree to incorporate these changes to fix terminology issue.
